title: 103_hr3464
content:
The Act titled "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes $15,000,000 for the modernization or replacement of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System used by the United States Forest Service to improve fire fighting response time. SEC. 3. IMPROVEMENT OF FIRE FIGHTING RESPONSE TIME.

The Forest Service, in consultation with local fire chiefs and experts, will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year.

SEC. 4. INCREASED CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR ARSONISTS. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders can now be fined or imprisoned for up to 10 years, with specific circumstances leading to harsher punishments. The penalties for offenses under this subsection are as follows: 
- If the damage exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and 5 to 20 years in prison.
- If a person's life is endangered or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the penalty is a fine and 8 to 30 years in prison.
- If personal injury occurs or the damage exceeds a certain amount, the consequences are severe. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $25,000,000 or if the death of any person results, the offender shall face a fine, imprisonment for not less than 10 nor more than 40 years, and potentially the death penalty. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years for offenses, with exceptions for circumstances like damage exceeding $1,000,000. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 5 to 20 years. If the offense places a person's life in jeopardy or causes damage over $10,000,000, the penalty increases to 8 to 30 years. If personal injury results or the damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender will be fined and imprisoned accordingly. If the death of any person results from reckless or negligent use of fire or explosive, the offender may face a fine, imprisonment for more than 25 years, or even the death penalty. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new provision stating that anyone who recklessly engages in conduct prohibited by certain subsections, resulting in destruction of a dwelling or injury to a person, may face fines, imprisonment up to one year, or both. If not imprisoned, the offender must serve probation with community service hours. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend a week in a residential institution and complete 400-2000 hours of community service. Negligent conduct violating specific subsections may result in a fine, imprisonment up to one month, or both. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend time in a residential institution and complete hours of community service. If convicted, the court may impose a fine, imprisonment up to one month, or both. If not imprisoned, probation with community service is mandatory. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire experts, will study legal barriers to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. Defense conversion aims to enhance private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo, other available planes, and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they will explore reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for firefighting. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study building roads and backup power for water supply in national forests to enhance firefighting. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. SEC. 8. REVENUE OFFSET. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
